results.title: The Soya bean
results.creator_credit: Birch Hill Film Productions, Unilever Films and Dudley Birch
results.brief_description: Soya beans, one of the oldest crops of man, are still a major product today. Illinois, USA, with its rich soil, gives the highest yield in the world. We follow a crop from the ploughing, harrowing and sowing in April to the harvest in autumn. The beans are used for margarine, cooking fats and oils; the residue, being high in protein, is ideal for animal feed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Birch Hill Film Productions, Unilever Films and Dudley Birch

results.title: The Soviet Union: the land and the people
results.brief_description: A geographical survey of the Soviet Union pointing out the diversity in land forms, climate and human activities. Four zones show the main differences in climate and soil - the northernmost belt or tundra region, the forest belt; the Black Earth Area; and the steppe lands. Industries range from hunting, trapping and lumbering to collective farming, mining and manufacturing. Great efforts are being made to utilise the countries natural resources especially for use in the manufacture of steel and in heavy industry.

results.title: The Soviet Union: life in Moscow
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Jules Power Productions, McGraw-Hill Films and Gene Feldman
results.brief_description: Portrays living conditions in Moscow in order to show the problems faced by the Soviet people as they attempt to build a modern, industrial urbanised society. The emphasis in the economy is changing from heavy industrial goods towards consumer products.

results.title: The Soviet Union: epic land
results.creator_credit: Novosti Press Agency, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Milan Herzog and Arnold Michaelis
results.brief_description: A survey of the Soviet Union revealing its immense size, diverse geographical features and great range of ethnic groups, from the Uzbeks in their agricultural setting to residents of the city of Moscow at their recreations. Songs and instrumental music native to the areas shown are heard throughout the film.

results.title: The Soviet Union: a student's life
results.brief_description: Looks at the structure of Soviet education, including early schooling, vocational schools, rigidity and difficulty of higher education. Explains the social and recreational life of students as well as the importance of school-state relationship.

results.title: The Soviet schoolchild
results.creator_credit: Soviet War Film Agency, Moscow Central News Reel Studios and Ministry of Information
results.brief_description: Soviet education from nursery schools to technical institutes and universities, showing the subjects taught and the methods of teaching at each type of school. The schools shown are situated in many different parts of the USSR.

results.title: The Soviet Circus
results.brief_description: A behind-the-scenes look at the everyday training and performances put on by the Moscow Circus School. The Soviet Circus encompasses acrobatics, lion- taming, magic and, of-course, the hilarious world of the clowns. The video captures all the glamour and excitement of this world famous circus troupe.

results.title: The Southern Cloud
results.creator_credit: Lions Club of Cooma and Cleve Maher
results.brief_description: Briefly covers the arrival of Charles Kingsford-Smith and C.T.P. Ulm in Australia after their trans-Pacific flight and the formation of the original Australian National Airways that commenced services in 1931. The Southern Cloud was lost in 1931 until its wreckage was discovered in 1958. Narration by James Dibble.

results.title: The South seas
results.creator_credit: Video Trip Corporation and Peter Teneyck
results.brief_description: A tour through the island paradises of the South Seas, including Tahiti, Moorea Island, Bora Bora, and Fiji. As a bonus there are tips on travel, accommodation, climate and food.

results.title: The Sounds of Aus: The Story of the Aussie Accent
results.creator_credit: Yael Bergman, David Swann, Lawrie Zion, Princess Pictures and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
The Australian accent has long been regarded as the most significant identifier of our cultural DNA and is arguably the most Australian thing about us. ‘The Sounds of Aus’ tells the story of the Australian accent, how it came about, how it has evolved over two hundred years of colonial and cultural history and how it is used in contemporary Australia. The accent reveals much about our identity, as individuals, as communities and as a nation. The Aussie accent has regularly been the battleground over which conflicts on identity have played out.
Presented with dry irony by raconteur John Clarke, ‘The Sounds of Aus’ debunks many common myths about the accent as we hear from a wide range of experts, from dialect coach Victoria Mielewska, phonetician Dr Felicity Cox, Oxford Dictionary editor Bruce Moore, and historians Michael Cathcart and Joy Damousi, to actors, comedians, and media performers such as; Rachel Griffiths, Bert Newton, Denise Scott, Santo Cilauro, Akmal Saleh, Max Gillies, Barry Crocker, Mary-Anne Fahey, and film director Bruce Beresford.
